label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, September 7, 1942
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding the president limiting all incomes to $25,000 and the subsequent issues this causes for their business affairs. Gertrude continues in her letter to relay news of friends, describe a Sunday she spent picnicking with friends, and describe her war job.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding the president limiting all incomes to $25,000 and the subsequent issues this causes for their business affairs. Gertrude continues in her letter to relay news of friends, describe a Sunday she spent picnicking with friends, and describe her war job.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
No5
Sept 7th
My Darling I dreamt last night so vividly that I was sitting in a room
with all the doors closed and suddenly the doors ppened and you walked
in the hugged me. I woke up- wide awake as though it really happenedand
I was wondering if it was just as you were going to bed at Pearl Harbor
and had hugged me. It was 5.05 A.M. I wonder what the difference in
time is between us.
I see where Forestal has been out there speaking to you all. To-night
the President made a speach.Did you listen? He said $25.000. was all
that any individual income would be allowed. I can see I shall have to
cut some wjere some how. I hate stopping wages but I think maybe we
will have to do somthing about Miss Finucan.
I wrote the Guaranty Trust last night to buy you 50 John Manswille and
15 Guaranty Trust- common stocks form you cash account. Doomis Sayles
advised it. I hope you approve.
My Darling I can hardly wait for your first letter. Maybe you gave one
to Jim Forestal to bring back? Are you living in a house? What is it
all like? How are you?.etc. etc.
Charlie Baskerville is all decked out as a Captain in the Air Co[r]ps. He
is to do some big painting jobs and his thrilled. After being in
uniform 48 hours he found himself winging his way with a big shot to
inspect West Point. I think he made his General laugh and that is how
he came to go along. He adored it. Every one asked him about difference
airplanes thinking he new all and ofcourse he did not know one from the
other. He really ahd a laugh at himself.
[End Page 1]
Have you heard the new definition of celaphane commission? ..........
You can see through it but it keeps off the draught.
I spent Sunday in Virginia at Marjorie and David Finley's. You know
Vandergracht built their house right on the Eustis estate .Its sweet.
Such a beautiful view of the mountains. We lunched. I played tennis
singles with Chip Bohlen[just returned from Japan] we swam in a pool
and I [r]eveled in the green grass, lush field, fat cattle and horses
and green corn. My it was peaceful and lovely. I do miss the country
terribly. It seemed so queer being in the country with out Clippy. My
I miss him so much. We went in my station wagon but it was worth the
two coupons to get there.
My job gets me home later and later. 7.30 to-night. I am so glad becaue
time really goes fast and there is less time here in the living room
thinking how I wish I was with you.
Do you want some books or pills or anything. Let me know.
Charlie Baskerville was so crippled with his back a few weeks ago that
he could not ven straigten up enough to life his hand and take the oat[h]
He went to the Specialst Dr Ober in Boston. He was examines.Ober said
he had one leg longer than the other, his pelvis was there for not on
an even keel which was causing all the trouble. He put a lift in his
heel [of his shoe] and now several weeks later he looks as thought he
has swallowed a ramrod. He is thrilled. I think you should get your bac[K]
set and wear a lift in your shoe too. Do you remember you tried it and
gave it up. I think you were om the right track and should try it again[.]
I have a glimmer of a hope for a house which I am to investigate to-
morrow. I hope it materialises. It would be wonderful. Anyhow I am fix[e]d
for one more month. When I move out of here Oct 1st I can move to Helen['s]
old house for the month of October as she is moving into her new oneon
[End Page 2]
2
that date and her lease does not expire till Nov. 1st so I shall rent
it off her hands and have a roof a little longer.
I have invited Mr. Newbold for dinner Wed night[at last] I have hired
the cook and am going to have Baskerville,Helen and Chi and Mrs Bohlem and
maybe Francis Stewart and Bill Ewing.
my book keeper is off on a trip to the roast beef country having just 
finished with the feaver areas. Things seem to be going alright.
Lots of love to you my sweet heart. I must say goodnight and go to
bed. How I would love to scratch your black curly head and kiss you ears.
My love to Morris.
Gertie
P.S. Sammy Trencher called me up on the phone from Virginia They wre there over
Labor Day. He said the theatres were going swell.and that Morris['] house had been
rented again.
[End Page 3]
